title: Insertion Sort
summary: A simple sorting algorithm that builds the final sorted array one item at a time, similar to sorting playing cards in your hands.

sections.title: Intuition
sections.contentMarkdown: Think of Insertion Sort like organizing playing cards in your hand. You pick up one card at a time and insert it into its correct position among the cards you've already sorted. The left portion is always sorted, and you insert each new element into its proper place.

sections.title: Time Complexity
sections.contentMarkdown:
- **Best Case:** O(n) - When the array is already sorted
- **Average Case:** O(n²) - For random arrays
- **Worst Case:** O(n²) - When the array is reverse sorted

**Space Complexity:** O(1) - Only uses a constant amount of extra memory

sections.title: When to Reach For It
sections.contentMarkdown:
✅ **Good for:**
- Small datasets
- Nearly sorted data (performs very well)
- Online algorithms (sorting data as it arrives)
- When stability is required

❌ **Avoid when:**
- Dealing with large datasets
- Data is completely random or reverse sorted
